I. 

 THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to China Water Affairs Group Limited (CWA) and China Water Affairs Investment Limited (CIL) 
for the Municipal Water Distribution Infrastructure Development Project in the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC).1  
 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Project Identification and Selection 

2. 
In response to the PRC's increasing challenges in ensuring livable cities and sustainable 
economic development, municipal environmental infrastructure has been a focus area of Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) private sector operations’ business development in the country since 
2006. The successful implementation of ADB’s municipal infrastructure projects funded by local 
currency  bonds2 generated  considerable  interest  among  private  sector  sponsors  and  financial 
institutions, as lack of access to finance has been a bottleneck for private participation in urban 
environmental infrastructure. It was discovered that CWA is a private sector front runner with a 
pioneering  business  model  and  strong  execution  ability.  Through  due  diligence,  ADB 
determined that the proposed project supports ADB’s strategies for environmental sustainability, 
inclusive growth, and financial and technical feasibility. In addition to facilitating investments by 
CWA,  ADB's  assistance  is  expected  to  bring  significant  developmental  benefits,  including 
supporting  private  sector  participation  in  the  newly  opened  water  distribution  subsector, 
catalyzing  local  and  international  commercial  financing,  and  supporting  the  government's 
objective of improving the urban environment in the country.   
 
B. 

Sector Background  

 

1. 

The Urban Water Sector in the People’s Republic of China 

3. 
Successful  economic  reforms  and  significant  growth  of  the  PRC  economy  have 
accelerated urbanization. The country’s urban population has more than tripled from 190 million 
in 1980 to 607 million in 2008, accounting for 45.7% of the national population; it is expected to 
account  for  55.0%  of  the  total  by  2020,  an  incremental  increase  of  about  200  million  people. 
This  demographic  shift  has  continuously  increased  the  need  for  water  access  and  reliability. 
Although  more  than  90%  of  the  urban  population  has  access  to  piped  water,  capacity  to  fulfill 
“last mile” connections to newly urbanizing areas is critically short.  
 
4. 
When the economy was centrally planned, the provision of water was considered a basic 
social right and was heavily subsidized by the government. Water supply companies owned by 
local governments owned charged limited fees for the consumption of resources and provision 
of services. This system led to a scarcity of capital for the construction, renovation, operation, 
and maintenance of water infrastructure. The lack of expansion and maintenance of pipelines,

combined  with  growing  demand  for  water,  has  resulted  in  widespread  water  inefficiency—

from water that is below national quality standards. 
 

2. 

Policy and Regulatory Framework 

The  government’s  water  policy  aims  to  (i)  develop  water  sources;  (ii)  protect  existing 
5. 
sources  by  controlling 
introduce  water-efficient 
industrial  and  residential  pollution;  (iii) 
technologies and operations; and (iv) implement appropriate pricing mechanisms to encourage 
conservation  and  generate  necessary  funds  for  operation,  maintenance,  and  investment.  The 
government’s  economic  and  enterprise  reform  programs  require  that  all  water  supply  and 
wastewater projects be financially sustainable and capable of recovering costs. 
 
 6. 
Oversight of the urban water sector is coordinated by the central government, which sets 
policies,  standards,  and  guidelines  for  drinking  water  quality;  wastewater  discharge;  and  the 
planning  and  construction  of  water,  wastewater,  and  drainage  infrastructure. 3  Provincial 
agencies set implementing regulations; approve selected actions of municipal agencies such as 
tariff adjustments, and large investment projects; and oversee compliance with water supply and 
wastewater  standards.  Municipal  governments  are  responsible  for  providing  water  and 
wastewater services, typically through a municipally owned company, and setting tariffs.  
 
7. 
Policies  to  commercialize  the  municipal  water  supply  sector  began  in  1998  with  a 
national policy mandating that urban water utilities earn a return on equity and introducing clear 
tariff-setting  procedures.4 Subsequent  directives  sought  to  commercialize  the  sector  further:  (i) 
the  10th  Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005)  recommended  setting  water  tariffs  according  to  supply 
and  demand,  and  the  11th  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010)  emphasized  improvements  in  water 
intensity  (i.e.,  reducing  the  amount  of  water  used  per  unit  of  economic  output);  (ii)  the  Water  
Law was revised in 2002 to allow customers to be charged for the volume of water consumed; 
(iii)  five  ministry-level  bodies,  including  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission 
(NDRC),  in  2002  jointly  issued  a  nationwide  framework  for  urban  water  tariff  determination, 
including  formalizing  the  requirement  that  operation,  maintenance,  and  debt  service  costs  be 
recovered through tariffs and other user fees;5 and (iv) various agencies have instituted a series 
of complementary policies, such as the “one meter per household” policy to reduce nonrevenue 
water6 and improve  water quality. In 2009, the NDRC and  the Ministry of Housing and Urban-
Rural  Development  (MOHURD)  announced  priorities  for  urban  water  distribution  tariffs: 7  (i) 
raising  tariffs  gradually  to  encourage  conservation  and  efficiency,  (ii)  increasing  transparency,

3 

(iii)  setting  block  tariffs  (progressive  by  volume)  to  encourage  conservation,  (iv)  establishing 
simple  sector  categories  for  tariffs,  (v)  incorporating  pro-poor  affordability  measures,  and  (vi) 
raising  public  awareness  of  water  issues.  In  its  first  policy  circular  of  2011,  the  State  Council 
emphasized  the  need  to  “accelerate  reform  and  development”  of  the  water  supply  sector, 
including the reform of tariffs.8 The 12th Five Year Plan (2011–2015) announced in March 2011 
further emphasizes water efficiency, with a 30% cut in water intensity targeted by 2015.   
 
8. 
According  to  the  national  tariff  guidelines,  water  distribution  tariffs  are  to  be  set  on  a 
cost-plus  basis,  including  the  costs  of  treated  water,  costs  of  distribution,  specified  rates  of 
return,  and  taxes.9 In  practice,  municipalities  are  raising  tariffs  at  varying  paces  to  reach  the 
mandated  levels  of  cost  recovery  and  returns.  The  average  residential  tariff  in  the  PRC’s  35 
largest cities at the end of 2008 was CNY2.4 per cubic meter, including CNY0.7 per cubic meter 
for wastewater treatment charges. By international standards, this tariff level is low: household 
water expenses in these 35 cities account for about 1% of total family disposable income, below 
the  global  average  of  2%–5%.  ADB  has  recommended  that  water  tariffs  be  increased  to  help 
promote  conservation  and  to  make  water  utilities  financially  sustainable,  and  has  encouraged 
municipal water authorities to “ensure the water tariff adjustment process is carried out smoothly 
and on-time.”10 
 
9. 
Quality  standards  are  increasing.  For  drinking  water,  new  standards,  which  were 
introduced  in  2006  in  line  with  World  Health  Organization  requirements  and  best  practices  in 
developed  countries,  have  increased  the  number  and  stringency  of  indicators  tested.11 Higher 
standards  increase  the  investment  requirements  for  treatment,  delivery,  and  monitoring  and 
testing systems. Moreover, the government has identified urban and rural water quality as a key 
development task for the 12th Five Year Plan.   
 

3. 

Private Sector Participation 

10.  While PRC water treatment and wastewater treatment projects have been undertaken by 
a  wide  range  of  private  sector  developers  since  the  late  1990s,  private  sector  investment  in 
these  areas  has  been  largely  based  on  the  build-operate-transfer  (BOT)  model.  Building  on 
policies  to  commercialize  municipal water  distribution  and  treatment  (para.  7),  the  government 
has encouraged private sector participation in the municipal water supply sector. In 2004, water 
distribution  in  medium-sized  and  small  cities  was  opened  to  joint  ventures  involving  foreign 
investors.  Further,  a  standard  concession  agreement  template  was  promulgated  to  facilitate 
private sector participation.12 In 2005 and annually during 2007–2010, the State Council issued 
policies  encouraging  the  investment,  construction,  and  operation  of  water  distribution  and 
treatment by private entities, and mandating municipalities to allow such participation.13

11. 
Nonetheless,  in  water  distribution  private  participation  has  remained  limited,  often 
involving  only  minority  investments  in  municipal  utilities.  Utilities  owned  by  municipal 
governments  still  own  and  operate  more  than  90%  of  the  PRC’s  municipal  water  distribution 
networks.  Given  the  substantial  level  of  investment  required  to  rehabilitate  and  expand  water 
pipeline networks and the limited self-financing capacity of municipal-owned utilities, increased 
private  ownership  and  operation  of  water  distribution  are  expected  to  improve  operational 
efficiency and help achieve the government’s water efficiency and quality goals.  
 
12. 
Financing  has  constrained  the  ability  of  private  sector  developers  to  scale  up  their 
operations.  In  studies  of  the  PRC  municipal  water  sector,  the  World  Bank  has  concluded  that 
financing  remains  one  of  the  critical  barriers  to  better  sector  performance. 14  Local  banks 
typically prefer to lend to large state-owned firms, and are averse to lending to newly privatized 
companies. Private companies also have difficulty tapping the enterprise bond market, as bond 
issuance in the PRC is time-consuming, complicated, and subject to numerous approvals.  
 
C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

The  project  is  consistent  with  Strategy  2020,  which  emphasizes  support  for  achieving 
13. 
poverty  reduction  and  inclusive  growth  through  environmentally  sustainable  development  and 
private sector development.15 The strategy identifies infrastructure and the environment as two 
of  the  five  core  areas  in  which  ADB  will  employ  its  financial  and  institutional  resources  to 
maximize  results,  efficiency,  and  impact.  In  terms  of  infrastructure,  the  project  is  in  line  with 
Strategy 2020’s emphasis on public–private partnerships and private sector engagement. ADB 
will  also  seek  to  improve  human  health  through  interventions  in  water  supply,  sanitation,  and 
waste  management.  With  regard  to  the  environment,  ADB  will  assist  developing  member 
countries  and  their  municipalities  in  addressing  a  range  of  problems  resulting  from  rapid 
urbanization. 
 

2. 

Consistency with the Country Strategy 

14. 
ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  the  PRC  is  based  on  four  development  pillars: 
(i) inclusive  growth  and  balanced  development,  (ii)  resource  efficiency  and  environmental 
sustainability, (iii) regional cooperation and public goods, and (iv) an environment conducive to 
private sector development.16 The project reinforces each of these pillars, with particular support 
for pillars (ii) and (iv). It will be integral to ADB’s efforts to help improve urban environment in the 
PRC.  
 
The  PRC  has  been  steadily  turning  to  development  that  is  market-oriented  and  led  by 
15. 
the  private  sector,  which  has  become  the  driving  force  for  economic  growth  and  job  creation. 
ADB’s private sector operations in the PRC have focused on infrastructure, energy, finance, and 
environmental improvement, and build on ADB’s public sector policy advice to the government 
on  private  sector  development.  For  infrastructure,  ADB  prioritizes  pioneering  projects  with

5 

innovative  contractual  and  financial  structuring  to  encourage  private  sector  participation, 
enhance  management  expertise,  and  improve  corporate  governance.  As  agreed  with  the 
government, ADB’s private sector operations focus on viable projects located in less-developed 
regions  and  explore  the  possibility  of  loans  funded  by  ADB’s  yuan-denominated  bonds.  As  a 
financially strong project focused mainly on a sector newly opened to private sector participation 
and with the option to be partly funded through a yuan loan, the project is consistent with these 
aims.  
 
The  project  will  be  consistent  with  ADB’s  country  strategy  in  the  PRC  and  will 
16. 
complement  ADB’s  overall  support  for  urban  development  in  the  PRC  through  investment 
projects  and  knowledge  products.  In  particular,  the  project  benefits  from  public  sector 
operations’ policy advice and lessons learned from public sector water supply projects.17  
 

3. 

Consistency with the Water Policy 

The  project  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Water  Policy, 18  which  emphasizes  careful 
17. 
management  and  participatory  approaches  to  conserve  water.  In  response  to  the  huge  unmet 
water  needs  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  and  consistent  with  the  recommendations  of  various 
international initiatives to double water investments, ADB has made water a core business area 
and envisages doubling its water investments to more than $2 billion annually.19 
 

III. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Description 

18. 
The  project  will  expand  and  improve  water  distribution  coverage,  develop  related 
transmission and treatment infrastructure, and increase the quality and reliability of water supply 
to cities through private sector participation.  
 

1. 

The Sponsor and the Borrowers 

The  project  will  have  two  borrowers:  CWA  for  the  US  dollar  tranche  and  for  the  yuan 

19. 
tranche, CIL, a holding company for CWA’s urban water supply operations in the PRC. 
 
20. 
CWA,  the  sponsor  and  the  borrower  representative  for  the  ADB  loan,  is  a  private 
company listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange. CWA specializes in urban water operations 
in  the  PRC.  Following  the  government’s  policy  to  encourage  private  sector  investment  in  the 
urban water sector, CWA was founded by a team of senior managers with strong water supply 
experience  in  the  PRC  and  a  good  reputation.  CWA  has  grown  rapidly  to  establish  itself  as  a 
pioneering private sector company in the PRC water supply industry..

 6 
 

 

CWA’s core value is optimizing water for cities. In 2003, CWA launched its operations as 
21. 
one of the first private companies to own and operate water distribution networks in the PRC. 
About 85% of CWA’s revenues are from water treatment and distribution, although the company 
also  operates  wastewater  treatment  plants  in  locations  where  the  local  governments  request 
CWA  to  expand  beyond  municipal  water  supply.  At  the  end  of  2010,  the  company  operated 
municipal  water  supply  utilities  under  concessions  or  similar  arrangements  in  23  cities,  with  a 
total distribution capacity of 4.1 mcm per day and wastewater treatment capacity of 0.2 mcm per 
day.20 CWA employs more than 4,500 people in the PRC. 
 
22. 
CWA’s  strategy  is  to  acquire  underperforming  water  supply  utilities  from  municipalities 
and improve their operational and financial performance. Many PRC distribution utilities owned 
by  municipal  governments  are  inefficient  and  undercapitalized,  often  leading  to  incomplete 
metering,  low  returns,  and  gradual  infrastructure  degradation.  CWA  expands  coverage  of  its 
subprojects  to  link  neighboring  networks  and  connect  new  economic  development  zones. 
Through technical improvements, CWA can reduce nonrevenue water and turn around a utility’s 
performance.21 CWA  replaces  outdated  pipes  and  reconfigures  network  layouts;  adds  pump 
stations  to  control  pressure  throughout  the  network;  and  locates  pipeline  leaks  with  centrally 
controlled pressure and flow monitors and acoustic detection equipment. By rehabilitating older 
pipeline systems, CWA also reduces secondary pollution caused by pipeline corrosion or other 
contamination. CWA installs meters at each end user and introduces billing systems to facilitate 
payment  (e.g.,  bank  debit,  prepaid  cards,  and  cash  at  CWA  service  counters)  and  service 
improvements  (e.g.,  24-hour  hotlines  and  rapid-response  repair  teams).  Through  these 
investments,  end  users  benefit  from  increased  water  availability,  stable  pressure,  water  at 
quality standards, and improved customer care. 
 
23. 
CWA  can  further  improve  operations  of  subprojects  through  the  introduction  of 
commercial  management  systems.  Standard  measures  introduced  at  newly  privatized  utilities 
include  (i)  seconding  senior  management  in  the  initial  stage  after  acquisition;  (ii)  setting 
company performance targets; (iii) creating key performance indicators (KPIs) for all staff;22 (iv) 
linking  KPIs  to  bonuses  and  promotions;  (v)  training  managerial  and  technical  staff;  and  (vi) 
sharing knowledge between the acquired utility and other subproject companies through senior 
manager rotations, company-wide  meetings to share experiences and best practices, and use 
of shared technical experts based at regional hubs. CWA also maintains a system of operational 
and financial reporting and benchmarking on a weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  
 

2. 

Project Design 

24. 
CWA  will  use  the  ADB  assistance  to  fund  a  series  of  water  treatment  and  distribution 
subprojects with total capacity of up to 2 mcm per day by FY2015. The project is designed to be 
a  least-cost  solution  to  financing  medium-sized  water  supply  projects,  the  financing  of  which 
involves  relatively  high  transaction  costs.  ADB  and  CWA  aim  to  finance  the  water  supply 
infrastructure  projects  on  a  portfolio  basis  to  reduce  financing  transaction  costs  and  diversify 
risk.  This  portfolio  approach,  broad  in  reach,  will  enable  ADB  to  provide  financing  support  for

recorded 3%–4% point average annual reductions in nonrevenue water during 2008–2010. 

22 CWA’s KPIs at the utility level include improvement in the nonrevenue rate; improvement in the fee collection rate; 
increases in operating efficiency (e.g., per-unit consumption of electricity, chemicals, or other inputs); reductions in 
operating  costs;  improvement  in  the  compliance  rate  with  water  quality  standards;  and  avoidance  of  operational 
failures or safety incidents.  These utility KPIs are mapped to individual-level performance targets for all staff. 

  

7 

multiple  water  supply  projects  that  are  often  too  small  and  time-consuming  for  ADB  or 
international banks to finance on a stand-alone basis.  
 
25.  Major investments at each subproject will be completed in the following five critical areas 
as soon as practical upon CWA’s takeover: (i) repairing or replacing old pipelines and upgrading 
water treatment plants; (ii) optimizing network connections by introducing pumping stations and 
changing  the  diameter  of  pipes;  (iii)  centralizing  management  and  dispatching  systems,  which 
involves a new information technology system, a network operation system, remote supervision 
of  the  network,  and  automation  of  pumping  stations;  (iv)  expanding  and  densifying  water 
distribution networks; and (v) expanding the water treatment plants after the network coverage 
reaches a critical mass.  
  
To  achieve  long-term  environmentally  sustainable  growth  and  to  set  standards  in  the 
26. 
fast-growing  water  supply  industry,  the  proposed  ADB  assistance  will  incorporate  loan 
conditions,  such  as  the  maintenance  of  a  transparent  corporate  governance  structure  and  the 
adoption  and  maintenance  of  an  environmental  and  social  management  system  (ESMS) 
consistent with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). These components of the project are 
expected  to  serve  as  best-practice  examples  to  CWA’s  peers  in  the  industry,  enhancing  its 
demonstration effects.  
 

3. 

Project Outputs and Outcome 

27. 
The  project  output  is  the  efficient  operation  at  designed  performance  levels  of  up  to  2 
mcm  per  day  of  water  supply  facilities  that  comply  with  ADB  safeguards  and  technical  and 
financial eligibility criteria. The project's expected outcome is improved water supply services in 
second- and third-tier cities.  
 
B. 

 
Development Impact 

1. 

Contribution to Economic Growth and Poverty Reduction 

28. 
The  project  directly  contributes  to  basic  human  needs  by  expanding  access  to  clean 
water and by mitigating secondary pollution during distribution of water to urban households and 
industries  in  second-  and  third-tier  cities  in  the  PRC.  Poor  people  are  most  vulnerable  to 
environment-induced diseases and are least capable of paying for adequate medical attention 
for digestive tract ailments associated with drinking polluted water.  
 
29. 
The  project  will  improve  water  efficiency  by  supporting  private  sector  participation  in 
water distribution to increase service quality and coverage, reduce costs, and improve financial 
viability. Reducing inefficiencies in water distribution and improving the supply of clean drinking 
water  is  a  component  of  pro-poor  development. 23  The  project  will  also  contribute  to  the 
government’s  long-term  plans  to  reduce  the  national  nonrevenue  water  ratio  to  12%.  Lower 
rates  of  nonrevenue  water  are  typically  associated  with  improved  tap  water  access  for  poorer 
urban households.24

2. 

Private Sector Development 

30. 
The project supports the government’s strategy to encourage private sector participation 
in  urban  water  supply  services  which  are  provided  mainly  by  municipal-owned  utilities.  Water 
supply  infrastructure  financed  by  the  project  will  thus  be  among  a  small  number  of  water 
distribution  utilities  managed  by  private  sector  in  the  country.  For  second-  and  third-tier  cities, 
the  project  will  support  capacity  additions  which  contribute  to  their  economic  plans.  The 
inclusion  of  best-practice  corporate  governance  conditions  in  ADB’s  loan  will  strengthen  the 
management  standards  for  operational  turnaround  through  privatization.  In  addition,  the 
project’s  B-loan  will  facilitate  international  lending  to  the  PRC  water  distribution  subsector, 
helping to address the constraints private developers face in securing private sector financing.  
 

3. 

Economic Sustainability 

31. 
The economic benefits are significant and include (i) the value of clean water delivered, 
(ii)  reductions  in  water  loss  during  distribution,  and  (iii)  unquantified  reductions  in  pollutants 
during  distribution.  The  expected  economic  internal  rate  of  return  from  the  quantified  benefits 
and costs is 18%.  
 
C. 

Environment and Social Dimensions 

 

1. 

Environment and Social Safeguard 

32. 
CWA will ensure that subprojects for ADB financing will comply with specified eligibility 
criteria and only include rehabilitation and expansion of water treatment plants and water supply 
networks. 25  These  water  treatment  plants  will  be  connected  to  rivers,  streams,  or  existing 
reservoirs  established  by  the  local  government.  The  project  is  classified  as  category  B  for  the 
environment as non-significant environmental impacts are anticipated. Pipeline networks will be 
rearranged,  new  pumping  stations  built,  and  water  treatment  plants  expanded  in  cities,  which 
may  require  small  parcels  of  land.  Hence,  the  project  is  categorized  as  B  for  involuntary 
resettlement and C for indigenous peoples. 
 
The  project  is  in  the  corporate  finance  category  under  the  special  requirements  for 
33. 
different finance modalities of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. The safeguard due diligence 
undertaken included a corporate audit of CWA’s ESMS, and past and present performance with 
regards  to  environmental  and  social  safeguards.  In  2008,  CWA  adopted  an  extensive 
environment,  health,  safety,  and  social  (EHSS)  management  manual  and  appointed  staff  to 
ensure its implementation. CWA has confirmed its commitment to revise the EHSS to meet the 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  requirements,  and  to  have  the  new  system  (including  the 
appointment  of  a  senior  manager)  and  capacity  building  plans  in  place  before  the  first 
disbursement.  
 
 

2. 

Gender, Labor, and Working Conditions 

34. 
CWA  upholds  gender  equality  and  provides  equal  employment  opportunities  for  men 
and  women.  Women  occupy  key  managerial  and  technical  positions  in  plants  visited  during 
ADB’s  due  diligence.  About  30%–40%  of  the  staff  members  required  to  run  the  plants  visited 
are women working in the administration, operations, and technical departments. CWA provides

9 

social  benefits  to  staff  members,  which  include  pension,  medical  insurance,  work  injury 
insurance, maternity leave, and a social housing fund. CWA has human resource policies and 
procedures covering recruitment, induction, rewards, disciplinary procedures, and labor contract 
management. The policies and procedures were formulated in consultation with employees and 
are  communicated  to  all  new  employees  during  induction.  CWA  will  ensure  that  contractors’ 
employment contracts include provisions covering core labor standards and national laws. The 
ESMS  will  include  requirements  to  monitor  the  working  conditions  of  workers  employed  by 
contractors  to  ensure  compliance  with  core  labor  standards  and  national  labor  laws  and 
regulations. 
 
35. 
The  design  of  water  supply  subprojects  to  be  financed  by  ADB  will  carefully  consider 
gender issues as part of the environmental and social assessment, and women will be involved 
in the consultations for future subprojects. These requirements will be outlined in the ESMS.  
 
D. 

Project Cost and Financing Plan 

The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  CNY2.6  billion  during  FY2012–FY2015,  including  the 
36. 
costs  of  acquiring  existing  assets,  rehabilitating  and  expanding  networks,  installing  electrical 
control equipment, and other installation expenses. ADB’s loan will fund part of the investment 
plan.  The  remaining  funding  is  expected  to  come  from  (i)  debt  financing  from  bilateral  and 
commercial banks, and (ii) internally generated cash from CWA’s operations.  
 
E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Development 

37. 
CWA  will  control  project  development  and  financing  arrangements.  CWA  will  acquire 
majority  share  ownership  and  management  control  of  municipal  water  supply  utilities.  Each 
acquired  utility  will  be  owned  by  a  subproject  company,  which  will  be  established  for  the 
purpose  of  rehabilitating,  expanding,  and  operating  the  utility’s  networks and  treatment  plants. 
This  subproject  structure  will  enable  CWA  to  respond  to  local  market  conditions  effectively, 
particularly  with  regard  to  issues  arising  from  the  quality  of  management;  operational  policy; 
budget,  financial  and  accounting  procedures;  and  network connectivity.  CWA  will  appoint  staff 
for all key management positions (including general manager, financial controller, and technical 
director)  and  will  have  full  control  over  (i)  management  policy;  (ii)  budget,  and  financial  and 
accounting procedures; and (iii) construction and operation.  
 

2. 

Anticorruption Policy  

38. 
CWA was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) and Policy 
on  Combating  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of  Terrorism  (2003).  Consistent  with  its 
commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will require CWA and 
CIL  to  institute,  maintain,  and  comply  with  internal  procedures  and  controls  following 
international  best  practice  standards  for  the  purpose  of  preventing  corruption  or  money 
laundering  activities  or  the  financing  of  terrorism  and  covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from 
engaging in such activities. The loan documentation between ADB and the borrowers will further 
allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings. 
 

 

 10 
 

3. 

Project Performance Monitoring, Reporting and Evaluation 

39. 
During  project  implementation,  ADB  will  receive  reports  regularly  on  its  financial  and 
operational  indicators,  as  well  as  other  information  that  ADB  and  CWA  will  agree  upon. 
Reporting  will  cover  (i)  the  financial statements,  (ii)  calculations  and  compliance  certificates  of 
the  financial  covenants,  (iii)  the  business  plans,  (iv) reports  on  the  progress  and  costs  of 
subproject construction, (v) the amount of water sold, and (vi) operation and maintenance and 
other administrative costs. ADB will conduct annual reviews to monitor environmental and social 
safeguard  compliance,  credit  assessments  of  the  subprojects,  and  a  review  of  development 
impacts, among other items. 
 
 

IV. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

1. 

Loan 

40.

loan  of  up  to  $100  million  funded  by  commercial  banks.  The  A-loan  will  have  two  borrowers: 
CWA  as  the  US  dollar  borrower  and  CIL  as  yuan  borrower.    The  A-loan  will  carry  an  interest 
rate and commitment and front-end fees as approved by ADB's Investment Committee.  
 
The B-loan of up to $100 million will have a maturity equal to or shorter than that of the

on a best-efforts basis.
